Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of an Instrument for Ultra-High Resolution 1S-2S Spectrosopy of Exotic Hydrogenic Atoms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Our most precise information about the structure and interactions of atoms is ultimately based on precise measurements of the light that is emitted and absorbed by various atoms and molecules. The spectrum of colors (or "resonant frequencies") of this light provides the basic input to calculations and measurements that are used for chemical identification, for reaction rate estimates, and for predictions of stability of new structures in a broad range of applications from medicine to defense and quality control in manufacturing. Recently, measurements on different types of hydrogen atoms (consisting of a central heavy proton and a planet-like electron or muon) are in disagreement about the radius of the proton. The discrepancy suggests one of 3 possibilities: (1) the theory of how charged particles interact, known as quantum electrodynamics or QED, is incorrect; (2) our knowledge of the structure of the proton is incorrect; or (3) there is some new kind of interaction or force of nature yet to be discovered. To decide whether the mystery is due to a problem with QED or not, two scientists from the University of California Riverside (UCR) propose to develop a novel instrument that will enable a measurement of the resonant frequency of positronium at ultimately 1000X more accuracy than the current state of the art. Because positronium is the simplest possible atom, consisting of an electron bound to an anti-electron, it should be described perfectly by QED theory. New measurements with the proposed instrument will decide whether QED theory is the problem and set significantly higher limits on the discrepancy in our understanding of the structure of the proton. The new instrument will lead to an improvement in the spectroscopy of unstable atoms at the frontier of the field of precision spectroscopy.

The purely leptonic atom positronium (Ps) is uniquely well-suited for testing bound-state quantum electrodynamics (QED) and provides the understanding and background by which we may extract non-QED physics out of precision atomic measurements on heavier leptons and hadrons. Few have dared to try measurements on positronium at the few parts per trillion level that would allow insight into physics such as the proton charge radius and higher level recoil effect corrections in muonium, and that might show differences between light and heavy leptons. The ideal level spacing for a precision measurement on positronium is the 1S-2S interval at approximately 1 233 607 216 MHz. Knowledge of the first 10 digits of this interval has stood for 20 years with an uncertainty of Â±3 MHz. The proposed instrument will implement several new techniques that would dramatically improve the accuracy of Ps atom spectroscopy and potentially other high resolution spectroscopy experiments by high precision individual atom trajectory analysis allowing line-centers to be measured to kHz precision. The laser frequency metrology during the transit of the atoms through the laser field will be accomplished with sub-kHz relative and absolute accuracies by recording the instantaneous deviations from the line-center of a thermally-stabilized ultra-low expansion glass reference cavity that is calibrated using a GPS-disciplined RF-referenced frequency comb. By providing ultrastable environmental, mechanical, and vibrational isolation, the overall specifications of the instrument will be sufficient to produce a narrow linewidth (~2 MHz), a reduction in systematic errors to enable up to 1000X increase in accuracy, and a 10X higher count rate to enable precision measurements in manageable measurement durations (months vs years).

POR.DRECONTENT:
An apparatus was designed and built incorporating state-of-the-art positron beam technology and laser spectroscopy techniques to perform ultra-high precision measurements on the exotic atom positronium. Positronium is a unique atom. Unlike most atoms found in nature made of protons, neutrons, and electrons, positronium consists of the positively-charged positron, that is the antimatter counterpart to the electron, and the negatively-charged electron. What physicists find so interesting about positronium is that it is only one of a handful of atoms made entirely of particles with no internal structure and that are thought to behave as perfect point-like particles. As such, the energy characteristics of this atom should be exactly calculable using a theory called bound-state quantum electrodynamics. This theory is accepted as the theory of how atoms are bound together and interact with light. It is considered by physicists to have been tested by so many experiments that it is assumed correct. However, tests on ordinary matter are complicated by the fact that protons have an internal structure and a finite charge radius. Precision measurements on hydrogen for example are not able to test the theory because there could be something wrong with the theory or with the corrections to bound-state quantum electrodynamics accounting for the finite charge radius of the proton.  The goal of the project was to build an advanced apparatus capable of making a 1000X higher precision measurement than previously possible on positronium which would be able to test the theory better than any previous measurement.

The intellectual merit of this project is in the innovations that were successfully designed and implemented in the instrument. In contrast to other atoms containing protons which are stable matter, the positronium atom is made from positrons that are by products of nuclear reactions, in this case by the radioactive decay of sodium-22. The number of positronium  atoms available for study is therefore many orders of magnitude lower than for ordinary matter atoms. A special positron beam apparatus to create a short burst of thermal positronium from a solid target was implemented to concentrate the few atoms in space and time to overcome the low signal detection problem. Also positronium has a very short life-time because it is unstable to annihilation. The ground state of the triplet state studied is only 142 nanoseconds. So the interaction time of the atoms with the light is only for ~100 nanosecond time-scale. A novel metrology method was implemented to determine the frequency of the light during the precise time that the atoms pass through the laser beam.  Because the atoms are 2000X lighter than hydrogen and the measured spectroscopy is shifted by a factor that is proportional to the square of the velocity, the precision required for this measurement requires that the trajectory and speed of each detected atom must be determined to better than 1% accuracy. A novel laser excitation scheme that increase the annihilation lifetime of the excited positronium to >10 microseconds allowed us to make a longer flight path between the nascent positronium atoms and detector. A novel time- and spatially-resolved detector was also implemented. These novel aspects of the apparatus enable the proposed precision measurements and are useful to other physicists and chemists who are interested in precision measurements of short-lived atoms or molecules.

The broader impact of this project is in the training of many students and postdocs and their potential for entering academia, industrial or government research careers. Over the four-year period of the project, 1 postdoctoral researcher, 10 Ph.D. graduate students and 11 undergraduate students participated. The postdoctoral research and one graduating Ph.D. student are currently employed in research positions. The other 9 graduate students will be completing their Ph.D. theses on this apparatus or other positron beam experiments. Of the 10 graduate students 1 is female and 5 are under-represented minorities. The 11 undergraduates worked mostly in summer however 2 completed senior honors theses on work related to the project and 3 have gone on to graduate programs in STEM fields. Of the 11 undergraduates, 3 are women and 5 are under-represented minorities. UCR is a Hispanic Serving Institution and the project has been especially productive in increasing the diversity of STEM participants. The project provided exceptional opportunities in training across subdisciplines in physics and in hands-on design and building of apparatus. The skill and experience of design and building a complex apparatus is relatively rare but is essential in the development of experimentalists in all fields and typically overlooked in many areas of science where the apparatus is commercially available. Appreciating the complexities of design of novel instrumentation is a nationally important skill which is essential not only in state-of-the-art science but in many aspects of engineering and manufacturing.
